Name: Manager Manager
Title: Some practice on KF
Text:
Hi all, for those who are interested in doing classroom observations but new to Knowledge Forum, you may need some practice to get familiar with the online environment students in GES will use in the new semester. So I have set up the account for all of you on KF and a new view for UAlbany research group to do some practice. 

1. KF account
    Rule: The username is your first name; the passcode is your first name and the first letter of your last name without space between them.
    e.g.(Dan Tao and Simona Pesaresi):
    Username: Dan          Passcode: dant
    Username: Simona     Passcode: simonap

2. Logging on
    The URL for KF is http://builder.ikit.org/  
    (1)Remember to choose the database for GES 2014-2015
    (2)Currently we are using the Basic version, Dr. Zhang? Click the "Basic" button to log on. 

If you have any questions in your practice, you can get help from this online help link: http://ikit.org/kf/46/help/enhanced/index.html Or email me. -Dan

Name: Alexa Madison Gabor
Title: Why you can't see well in the dark
Text: The reason you can't see well in the dark is because the retina in your eyes take in light to see. When it's dark, the retina expands to try and take in more light. Since there's not much light in the dark, your retina takes in as much as it can and it's harder to see.

Name: Nellie Grace Cordi
Title: high standards nellie
Text:
I can write with both my left and right hand. My handwriting isn't perfect either way but you may have better handwriting on your left. It's odd the way it works, but it is what is. Everyone is different. If you have better handwriting on your right, you are in the average zone because most people are right-handed. If you write with your left hand it's just a bit different. I think  I'm just weird because I can write either way. I am practicing the right hand as an experiment, though. 

Time to test the "practice makes perfect" theory! 

Nellie

Name: Joanna Dorcas Andrews
Title: genetics is...
Text:
Genetics are like cells from your parents that give you certain traits.  If your mom has brown hair, and your dad has black hair, and you have a brown and black genes, you will get brown hair because brown is the dominant gene for all colors of hair. But, if you have 2 black hair genes, you will have black hair. 
you will always have 2 hair genes.

Name: Ian Zhang
Title: Nervous system
Text: In the nervous system there are two main nervous systems, the central nervous system and the peripheral nervous system. There are also many neurons, and many neurons make a nerve. Two types of neurons are efferent and afferent. Efferent neurons carry things away from the central nervous system and the afferent neurons carry things to the central nervous system. When you look at the central nervous system and peripheral nervous system combined into one picture, it looks like a tree. The brain is the leaves, the "spine" the trunk, and the peripheral nervous systems look like the roots.

Title: Interesting facts and theories about heart attacks
Text:
To be healthy, the coronary arteries For food and oxygen must be clean and open. when plaque from fatty food forms and builds up in them, blood cannot get to the heart, causing the heart muscle to die out. This causes a heart attack.

If the heart dies, the brain dies, which means you die. However, people survive heart attacks! How do they survive them? What else helps people live through heart attacks? Could the help come from a heart transplant? Or could it be something bigger?...

Recessive genes: Carried genes.

Title: Here is some good facts about the heart
Text:
1.  Your heart is a powerful muscle in your chest
2.  The heart is made out of two pumps one on the right and one on the left
3.  Each of the pumps are made out of an atria and a ventricle
4.  The atria brings blood back into the heart and pass it to the ventricle which pumps the blood back out
5.  Your heart rate increases when you run and pay and even when your nervous
6.  Blood takes oxygen and nutrients to every cell in your body

Name: Nellie Grace Cordi
Title: Running makes the heart beat fast... some facts for you!!!
Text:
- Running makes the heart beat fast! This lets more oxygen into the body through the lungs! That's why you breathe heavier when you run!

-Blood cells use food and oxygen to make energy. But too much food can slow you down. That's sort of odd?...

- The Aorta carries blood to all of the other arteries in your body. That includes the Heart and Brain.

- To be healthy, your coronary arteries must be clear of fatty foods (so eat healthy!). Otherwise plaque can build up making it a struggle to carry blood to the heart and brain. After awhile, the heart could begin to die out... also known as a heart attack.

Name: Pretesh Prakash
Title: how your eyes see five senses
Text:
Your eye sees by ;

1. Your eye uses light to see the picture.
 
2. Light goes though the lens that is held together by the ciliary musle. 

3. Than the picture to the screen at the back of the eye called the retina.

4. The picture is sent to cones and rods to get the colors right. 

5. The optic nerve sends the picture to the brain. 

6. The Brain sees the picture the wrong way so it flips it over to the right way.

So all of the parts of your eye have to work real hard so you should take care of your eye.

Name: Emily Grace Ravalli
Title: neurons
Text:
Neurons are specialized cells that make up your nervous system. Neurons handle walking around, feeling pain, and remembering important things. There are three different types of neurons. The first neuron is sensory neurons. Sensory neurons send  to signals from sense organs like eyes, ears, skin, spinal cord, or brain. The second kind of neurons are called motor neurons. Motor neurons tell muscles to move. The last of kind of neurons are called interneurons. Interneurons are messengers, they send messages between the sensory and motor neurons. 

Also written by: Mia Hoffman

Name: Sean Michael Hickey
Title: runner's knee (table)
Text:
This disease happens: overuse of joints, running/walking on hard or uneven surfaces, poor shoes, or to little warm-up.

The symptoms are: tenderness and aching under knee bone (patella).

The preventions are: Good amount of warm-up, even surfaces, and wearing good shoes for running/walking.

The treatment is: medical drugs, rest, or wearing a knee brace.

Name: Sean Michael Hickey
Title: Sprained joints table
Text:
Cause: joint gets overstretched or twisted to far out of position.

Symptoms: joint is sore and is unable to bear any pressure. 

Prevention: warm up befor any exercise activity.

Treatment: rest the joint. Apply ice to reduce swelling.

Name: Sean Michael Hickey
Title: Stress fractures table
Text:
Cause: repeated use puts too much pressure on certain bones.

Symptoms: sharp pain in the bone, especially in ones that bear weight.

Prevention: warm up before activity. Vary movements. Wear good shoes.

Treatment: rest is needed but can take months. Exercise is allowed if not weight-bearing.

Text:

Title: spinal cord nerves
Text: The spinal cord is made up of a lot of nerves. If the nerves are damaged in the spinal cord they don't grow back. The higher the injury on the spinal cord the more body it affects. An injury low in the spinal cord may paralyze your legs.  An injury high in your neck area can cause paralysis from the neck down, including your legs and arms.

Name: Mia Marie Hoffman
Title: brain and nervous system
Text:
your brain is like a central computer and the wires is the nervous system. your brain controls heart beat, breathing, and all other systems that keep us alive. your brain stem is in the back of the neck. Theres 2 different kinds of nervous systems. The first nervous system is the peripheral nervous system carries signals. The second nervous system is the automatic nervous system controls heart beat, food digestion, and breathing [brain does the same but this nervous system is like a back up just in case]. The brain is grayish pink, soft, and looks like a walnut. The largest part of the brain is the cerebrum, which takes up four-fiths of the brain. the cerebellum is another part of your brain, which controls balance and coortanation. The right cerebrum controls the left cerebrum and the left cerebrum controls the right side. 

Also written by Emily Ravalli

Name: Snigdha Arige
Title: the digestive track
Text:
the digestive track makes a path for the food you swallowed to follow :

the mouth, which is a chamber containing the tongue and the teeth.

the esophagus, which is a strong muscular tube connecting the mouth to the stomach.

the stomach,which is a wide stretchy bag that sits below the oesophagus on the left side of the body.

the small intestine, which is a narrow but really long pipe/tube that sits curled up in the middle of the abdomen.

the large intestine, which is a wide channel that sits around the small intestine.

Name: Mia Marie Hoffman
Title: How the brain controls everything
Text:
The brain controls everything by sending messages to different parts of your body.  Different parts of the brain control different thing like the cerebellum controls movement. The cerebrum controls your voluntary movement. The thalamus sends most messages and the brain stem controls your heart beat, blood pressure and other things that keep you alive. Also the brain stem is connected to the spinal cord which, is like a highway for messages. The Medulla Oblongata is an enlarged continuation of the spinal cord. The Medulla Oblongata regulates the rate and depth of breathing.

Also written by:Emily Ravalli and Hena Shiju

Title: How your brain holds memories and thought
Text:
Short term memories are based in the cerebral cortex, but the memories soon fade away. Unless the memories are important or remembered several times are stored in the hippocampus. Some memories cam be kept for months, weeks, or years. Two disease that affect your memories are Alzheimers and Amnesia. Alzheitmers disease deposits build up and nerve  cells stop working which, leads to memory loss. Amnesia is when someone can't remember things that happened recently and things that happened long ago. Also drugs and alcohol can severly damage brain/ memory

Title: Possible answers to your issue...
Text:
Dear Alexa,

My opinion is that it was mold or dust or pollen because they are very common allergens. Also if you had a dog, a cat, some other pet, or if you lived near any exotic outdoor animals that you were exposed to (no offense to the deer of the wood!) you may be allergic to animal dander. These are all common allergies.

As for why nothing has happened since the reaction I will need more information on the reaction and some more facts. I will look for an answer in my research.

-Nellie Grace Cordi

Name: Christian Andrew Jahnel
Title: Yawning
Text: Yawning cools your brain when it is in heated states . Yawning can mean that you are tired, but that is because when you sleep your brain heats up fast.  This also brings me to my other research: your body has biological clocks and if you set a real alarm it can cause sleep inertia. Sleep inertia is basically grumpiness when your body is usually awake in a sleepy state. The deeper sleep you're in the heavier sleep inertia. You should get about 7 hours of sleep. So, this is why you shouldn't set an alarm or stay up too late. But, don't  sleep too long or your body will restart it's biological stages and when you wake it will probably be in deep sleep, which will cause super heavy sleep inertia. In conclusion, watch how much you sleep. YAAAAY!

Title: Back of Brain
Text:
Guys I have some info that might encourage you to wear a helmet when biking. The back of you brain controls some pretty important things. 
1-Pons controls your ability to wake up
2-Medula Oblongata controls breathing and heartbeat and sends info to spinal cord
3-Cerebellum helps coordinate your body

A few reasons to be safe on bikes

Name: Vincent James Carsillo III
Title: bone marrow
Text: Bone marrow produces 500 billion cells per day.  Also it takes up 4% of a average humans weight.  Bone marrow produces hemopoiective cells which makes red+white blood cells also it makes stromal cells, that produces fat, cartilage and bone. Their's 2 types of marrow, red and yellow.  Red marrow makes red blood cells and platlets and yellow marrow makes white blood cells.

Text: Well that's only because light takes time to get to Earth. For example, light from the sun takes eight minutes. So, correct me if I am wrong, I do not believe the same thing happens with objects on Earth. Everything you are seeing is in real time, and the brain flips over images you see because they're upside-down. But still, it does it very fast. But sunlight and starlight are from a time ago. Name: Alexa Madison Gabor
Title: A Lucid Dream
Text:
Hey guys. Do you know what a lucid dream is? 

A lucid dream is a dream that you are in control of. You can control yourself and do anything. Unlike regular dreams, lucid dreams you are conscious of. You know it's a dream and you can usually remember it well. The first lucid dream you get, you might get very excited and wake up. It's hard to get it back then. But, if you are not aware that it's a dream, here are some steps you can take to tell

-Try to watch a clock. Clocks in dreams don't change, so if a dream clock is at 9:45, it will stay at 9:45.

-Try to press your finger through your hand. The density in dreams are messed up and your finger will go through your hand.

-Try to fly. In real life you're not going to be able to fly.

Title: homes for viruses
Text: Your body is like a home for viruses and germs. Many microscopic viruses live in your body, such as dust mites and tape worms. Other creatures that you can see latch on for a bit. Mosquitoes only stay on your body for a couple of seconds but can spread the disease malaria. Malaria can cause fevers, fatigue, vomiting and headaches. If it is a bad case of malaria it can cause seizures,coma or death.

Name: Alexa Madison Gabor
Title: Synesthesia
Text:
Synesthesia is something that speeds up the signals on the nerves, causing your sensory system to be messed up. A common synesthetic thing is associating colours with letters, days of the week, tastes, smells, and sounds.
Tastes can also be associated with sounds and smells (i.e. tasting waffles when seeing the colour green, causing synesthetes to say the taste is 'green' and no one will know what it means.) Synesthetes often don't know they have synesthesia, they think everyone can taste colours, thinks Wednesday is purple, ect. until they find out most people can't perceive things that way. A rare type of synesthesia is associating tastes with words. For example, when hearing the word, basketball, you taste pineapples. A test for synesthesia or ideathesia is drawing an angular shape and a round shape and asking the person which shape they would name 'Bouba' and which one they would name 'Kiki'. 95% of people chose Bouba for the round shape, and Kiki for the angular one.

Title: Heart and Blood
Text: First you breath in the oxygen from the air.  Then it goes to your lungs.  Then your blood picks up the oxygen and goes to the heart.  Then the heart gives the blood a little push so it can make it around your body.  When your blood gets to a part of the body it lets the oxygen go so that your body can take it and changes it to carbon dioxide. Then your blood picks up the old air or carbon dioxide and brings it to your lungs so you can exhale the air or carbon dioxide.

Title: Question #4 How blood gets to you heart
Text: lungs
column9:
In location A there is carbon-dioxide blood that came from the body cells.while in location B,it is oxygen blood that goes
 to the heart ready to be pumped to the body cells. Oxygen blood has lust been through the lungs going to the heart while
 carbon-dioxide blood went through the body cells, back to the heart, then to the lungs to be exhaled. 

Blood keeps your blood cells warm. Blood cells warm. Blood also carries oxygen through your body. 
One more thing that the blood does to help your body cells is it transports nutrients and substances to them.

Name: Kendra Caroline Burke
Title: DNA and RNA difference
Text: DNA is a long polymer with deoxyriboses and phosphate backbone. Having four different nitrogenous bases: adenine, guanine, cytosine, and thymine. RNA is a polymer with a ribose and phosphate backbone with four different nitrogenous bases: adenine, guanine, cytosine, and uracile.

Name: Snigdha Arige
Title: Digestion
Text:
By: Mia, Mariana, Snigdha, and Alex

First, the food travels down the esophagus. Next, it goes to the stomach. Then the food turns into a liquid called chyme. Then, the  chyme goes into the small intestine. The small intestine is outlined with villi. Then the villi extracts the nutrients from the chyme. After, the nutrients get into the bloodstream. The blood there takes the nutrients to the brain and other organs.

Name: Ian Zhang
Title: Nervous System Summary
Text:
<Warning!> This a summary of everything I posted and more.
-CNS: The central nervous system (CNS)controls our body/bodies. It includes our brain. The CNS includes the ANS and SNS (see below). The CNS looks kind of like a tree. The CNS interacts with mostly everything in the human body.
-ANS: The autonomic nervous system (ANS) controls muscles, organs, glands, etc. It has 3 systems in it, which work together to create the ANS: The enteric, sympathetic,and parasympathetic nervous systems. The enteric nervous system is in charge of the gastrointestinal system (The system that has to do with waste. Say no more). The parasympathetic nervous system is in charge of digesting, and resting. The sympathetic nervous system is in charge of your instincts to danger. [The ANS associates with (like I said) the muscles, organs, glands, etc.
-SNS: The somatic nervous system (SNS) allows you the ability to think. It may sound small, but it's a big job. If you didn't have the ability to think you couldn't walk! It associates with the brain.
-Neurons: 2 types of neurons are efferent and afferent. They carry messages to and away from the CNS. Neurons have many parts. To find out the names of the parts, check out Tyler and I's poster. There are sensory, relay, and motor neurons. Sensory neurons carry signals from different parts of your body to the spinal cord and brain. Relay neurons carry messages from one part of the central nervous system to another. And finally, motor neurons carry signals from the central nervous system to parts of the body. The neurons carry messages across the nervous system. It works with the CNS. 
And that is the end, finally.
Ask questions if you're questioning something.

Name: Alexander Ran Madeksza
Title: Parts of the brain
Text:
There are three parts of the brain the cerebrum, limbic, cerebellum, medulla oblongata and the brain stem. There is a thin gray tissue covering the brain
The medulla oblongata keeps your breathing regulated

-ANS: The autonomic nervous system (ANS) controls muscles, organs, glands, etc. It has 3 systems in it, which work together to create the ANS: The enteric, sympathetic,and parasympathetic nervous systems. The enteric nervous system is in charge of the gastrointestinal system (The system that has to do with waste. Say no more). The parasympathetic nervous system is in charge of digesting, and resting. The sympathetic nervous system is in charge of your instincts to danger. [The ANS associates with (like I said) the muscles, organs, glands, etc.
-SNS: The somatic nervous system (SNS) allows you the ability to think. It may sound small, but it's a big job. If you didn't have the ability to think you couldn't walk! It associates with the brain.
-Neurons: 2 types of neurons are efferent and afferent. They carry messages to and away from the CNS. Neurons have many parts. To find out the names of the parts, check out Tyler and I's poster. Name: Zoey Levine
Title: Supper Answer #1
Text:
We think the sensory neurons, muscles, and the brain all help you prevent a burn. We think this because the sensory neurons feel that an object is to hot or warm. Then the sensory neurons send signals to the brain to move your hand (or other part of the body.) The brain sends signals to the muscles, so the muscles can move the part that is getting burned. The sensory neurons help you feel warmness, coldness, and pain........Skin sends info to the brain through the affrent nerve to the brain. The brain sends a signal back through the effrent nerve to the muscles. Also the affrent nerves is a nerve that carries impulses toward the central nervous system. Finally the effrent nerve is a nerve that 
conveys impulses toward or to the muscles or glands. In conclusion, we think the sensory neurons, muscles, brain, and affrent and effrent nerves all help you prevent a burn. IF YOU HAVE ANY QUESTIANS THEN JUST ASK Zoey, Willow, Nick, and or  James

Text:

     However, your theory could be correct. Everyday, your brain is constantly changing your memories. However, when it happens, you're not aware of it. The change makes some of the memories fake! So when you dream, a random memory in the back of your brain could stimulate a random dream. A newer memory could cause a realistic dream, and a older one could cause a world of fantasies.

Name: Alexa Madison Gabor
Title: Alice in wonderland syndrome
Text:
I can tell you about a neurological thing called Alice in wonderland syndrome, more commonly called ACM (acute confusional migraine). It is exclusive migraines for pre-teens and teens but it is extremely rare for adults. Once the teen who has it turns to adults it will turn into just very bad migraines. Only 4% (I forgot the number) of population has them. The symptoms include:
Confusion (earning it's title of Alice in wonderland syndrome)
Hallucination
Memory loss
not recognize people
no headaches (only 50% of the time there will be headaches.)
Lightheadedness
Having a hard time distinguishing dreams and reality
Fogginess
Not making sense with words/using weird word combinations (i.e. white cow run sky) 
glassy eyes and dazed
Light sensitivity
spacing out
Anyways, my question is how does this happen? What in the brain makes this response happen? I have alice in wonderland syndrome but I take medications. I listed the symptoms of my own time. It is different for each person.

Title: super answer for #2 on the test
Text:
Question A - Our theory is that the air we breath in is full of oxygen which is good for your muscles and organs. While the air you breath out has your muscles and organs, carbon waste. A.K.A  Carbon Dioxide.

Question B - Once the air comes in through the mouth and nose it goes through the Larynx, into the Trachea, then to the Bronchial tubes, then into the lungs. Next oxygenated blood goes through the pulmonary artarys, gathers the oxygen then goes back to the heart. The heart then sends the blood through the veins to muscles and organs like the brain, kidneas, triceps, biceps,abs, calves, ECT. Eventully after dropping off oxygen and picking up carbon dioxide, blood goes back to the heart through the veins and into the lungs through the pulmonary artarys to drop off the carbon dioxide and pick up more oxygen so the whole cycle starts again.

Name: George Qu
Title: color and UV
Text:
Your eyes detect light that bounces off an object. The light is call UV(Ultra-violet). The object absorbs a part of the light spectrum and goes into your eyes. Your color cones take part here. They act like a prism, where regular UV goes in, but comes out a rainbow! The object absorbs only part of the spectrum, so only some colors appear. The brain converts the divided UV into what 
we call "color".
      "Color" is actualy a illusion. Optical illusions you see in books or on the web is an image that finds the imperfections of our eyes. Our senses aren't perfect, so when a certain thing happens that our brains can't fully process, we see (or feel, or taste etc.)a illusion appears.

   My question, what is the real world like? We are limited only by our brains and our senses. so what does the real world like?


    Got an answer? Build-on to this note. Thanks!

Title: This is not my view... please read
Text:
THIS IS NOT AN ADVERTISEMENT. IT IS AN INFORMATIONAL POST.
This is a theory I found from online research under the idea of the immune cycle. It is not exact. I wanted to show you that allergies move through the blood so I posted it here on the blood view.
1. When you get a cut, bacteria and germs enter your body. If the cut is deeper, it can enter your bloodstream, causing a possible set of diseases.
2. Immune cells go there when an unknown substance (allergy) gets into you and forms an allergen.
3. The cells fight hard and cause a huge response... a.k.a. reaction.
4. Then the cells eliminate the invading substance.
5.The reaction slowly goes away until it has gone completely.
SO, I hope you liked learning about it! Check out more like this on my view... allergies/immune system... and more cool build on facts to come!!
+NELLIE GRACE CORDI-GES TREASURER

Title: Cones
Text:
This is just a theory, it may or may not be true.
There are three types of cones, red, blue, and green. The light enters the pupil and then the cornea bends it, making the picture upside-down. It passes through the rods and cones which perceive the light and colours. The red, blue, and green mix together to make different colours. Then the picture is sent to the brain who turns the image right side- up before you see it. Also, I do not think there is a colour nerve.

Name: George Qu
Title: not exactly
Text:
Your body absorbs nutrients, but they don't exactly turn into energy.
  Heres my version of the process: food goes down your throat
and into your stomach, which breaks the food down into glucose and carbohydrates. Then they go into the intestines, which squeeze the remaining food and mix it with body acids and juices. The nutrients in the food get absorbed. The body produces insulin, a hormone that balances blood sugars so the energy doesn't go in the blood all at once. Yes, the carbs and glucose do provide energy, but the nutrients are absorbed into your body.

Name: Willow Anne Novak
Title: Vocal Cords (Lrynax)
Text: Did you know that your voice box is also call your lrynax. Your lrynax is what holds your true vocal cords and your false vocal cords. It is made up of cartilage, muscles, and ligaments   The reason we have false vocal cords is so they can protect the true vocal cords. Also known as muscular fold that protect the true vocal cords.  The false vocal cords don't help with any vocalization, but they help when you are grunting and screaming.  Your vocal folds are 2 elastic membranes that go across the lrynax. When you are talking your muscles tighten up, and push you true vocal cords together.  The true vocal cords vibrate when you are talking. The vibrating makes the sound. The speed of the vibration helps make different sounds. Your lips and tongue help make more complex sounds.

Name: Elizabeth Ashley Irwin
Title: Bone Facts
Text:
Hear are some facts on bones that I learned 
* bones heal by the body producing many new cells that cover both ends of the bone until the ends are fused together again
* there are 7 different types of fractures
* the worst fractures are called either a comminuted fracture- bone is broken in more than 2 places or shattered, or a open fracture- bone is sticking threw the skin
* the least bad fracture a kid can get is a bowing fracture- bone bends but doesn't brake
* the least bad fracture an adult can have is a greenstick fracture- bone is broken on 1 side not all the way threw
* also sometimes people will pass out, feel dissy, or be cold

Name: Natalie Rose Moffre
Title: Sleepwalking
Text: Sleepwalking is a sleep disorder belonging to the parasomnia family. Sleepwalkers arise from the slow wave sleep stage in state of a low consciousness and perform activities that are usually performed during a state of full consciousness. The sleepwalker can't respond during the event and usually doesn't remember it. In some cases, he/she may talk and not make any sense. Sleepwalking mostly happens in childhood.

Title: Retina
Text: When it is day/light, your retina will shrink your pupil because there is enough light to see fine, and they don't need extra. When it is dark, your retina will dilate, or expand to take in as much light as possible because there isn't enough light to see normally. I hope this helps :)

Name: Alexa Madison Gabor
Title: Diagnosis
Text: You don't need to be diagnosed with synesthesia. But, there are common tests to determine if your really have it, or you just are weird. Two tests include drawing an angular shape, and a rounded shape. The tester will ask the patient to say which one they will call "Bouba" and which one they'll call "Kiki". 95% of people said that the angular one is Kiki and the rounded one is Bouba. Another test is that there will be a paper with many fives on it. the tester will ask the patient what they notice about them. If the patient is a synesthete, they will say they notice that the fives are forming some triangles and one is backwards. Non-synesthetes will say that one of the fives is backwards. One cannot have slight synesthesia, but different types including ideathesia, which everyone has a little of, and lexicon synesthesia where you associate a sound with a taste. Those are of I remember. Also, most people are born with synesthesia, but they think everyone has it until someone tells them, so you are never to young to have synesthesia.

Title: My Theory: How can humans prevent migraines?
Text:
We have genetics and so that's how we have different types of reactions (pains). Medicines are preventions and so certain medicines work better than others, based on your genes.

Looking at this simple information in basic form, you can see some people won't get migraines, just a headache once in a while. This is all based on genetics.

With a second glance you may have noticed this fact: medicines are preventions. So, they will prevent whatever horrible reactions your genes bring on (for me it's migraines).

I hope you finally saw with a studying eye that genes not only carry through pains, but pain preventions. My question is, What are some ways we can use genetics to find medicines that relieve migraines and other headaches?

Name: Alexa Madison Gabor
Title: Evolution
Text: Well we started out as Homo Erectus, (kind of like neanderthal/caveman) and had a lot of hair and couldn't speak. When the first humans stood on their legs they became dominant. They tamed wolves and turned them into dogs for hunting. Slowly languages started happening. We made tools and stopped being nomadic and created the first villages. We began to evolve into Homo Sapien, what we now know as modern humans. We lost our neanderthal skulls and bones, and became stronger and less hairy. Anyways, we started having technology, taming more animals, building cities until we took over the world.

Name: Alexa Madison Gabor
Title: Alexa: How does bone marrow make blood?
Text:
How does bone marrow make blood?


Journey of thinking:

In the beginning I found a fact that bone marrow was gooey and spongy and that threw me off course. I didn't think it could make blood. So I ask the question. James replied with this note, which is a very good theory:
maybe it [sic] squzzes out the blood. if so i still wonder what the combanation of chemicals are in blood? just a thought.
That started the alpha-thread. Many people replied to this now hot topic. Many theories and research points popped up, such as maybe there are pores in the bone. The knowledge advanced because many people theorized and found new information I also made a SmartArt showing the bone marrow process. The big idea grew and grew until I found this information: stem cells in the bone marrow split apart and form into blood cells. This new info ended the discussion. By January, everyone (except for one or two people) had long since moved on. The alpha-thread still is the biggest thread out there, but long since died off, and it is no longer a hot topic. The blood, veins, and bone marrow view is pretty inactive, except for a few rogue threads with no question and just a fact. I am now researching epilepsy, very far off the topic of bone marrow.

Title: Joanna: How does the immune system work?
Text:
Journey of thinking

In the beginning... we started with talking about the immune system,but no one knew much about it. The notes were shorter, and less advanced. We were trying to find a definition for Immune. Here is a note from september:

   By: Joanna Dorcas Andrews At : 2014-09-26 04:27
If you get chicken pox when you are little, you will most likely never get it again. that means you are immune to chicken pox. When you are immune to a germ your cells can recognize it and kill it before it can make you sick.
Then the Knowledge advanced because... Now that people knew what Immune was, they started leaning toward studying Allergies. At first the notes were not very advanced, but as we continued our research they got a lot better. For example, this note is from when we started studying Allergies:
 
Not my study point (View:Siebel: How Does the Immune System Work?)
By: Alexa Madison Gabor At : 2014-10-30 23:48
But it's a flaw in the immune system when something enters the body and your body mistakes it for an intruder and makes antibodies to attack it when really it can't do anything.
      Here is a note from after we had done research on Allergies:        

Allergy 3 (View:Siebel: How Does the Immune System Work?)
By: Nellie Grace Cordi At : 2015-01-16 09:01
This is all because of the "unknown substance". When you get seasonal allergies (i.e. autumn), the leaves from maple trees bother your sinuses... they are getting your nose to run, or maybe even tickle, and sometimes you get sick. Histamine is in your body. That's when your parents make you take a medicine called an antihistamine to fight off allergens and reactions in your body. The reactions are really just overreactions to an "unknown substance". If you are allergic to maple trees, you should not be out much in fall! 
          In the end, studying Allergies led us to the topic of Migraines. Our research helped us make theories. Here is an advanced note from our research for Migraines:
Alice in wonderland syndrome (View:Siebel: Brain)

By: Alexa Madison Gabor At : 2015-01-23 08:12

I can tell you about a neurological thing called Alice in wonderland syndrome, more commonly called ACM (acute confusional migraine). It is exclusive migraines for pre-teens and teens but it is extremely rare for adults. Once the teen who has it turns to adults it will turn into just very bad migraines. Only 4% (I forgot the number) of population has them. The symptoms include: 
Confusion (earning it's title of Alice in wonderland syndrome) 
Hallucination 
Memory loss 
not recognize people 
no headaches (only 50% of the time there will be headaches.) 
Lightheadedness 
Having a hard time distinguishing dreams and reality 
Fogginess 
Not making sense with words/using weird word combinations (i.e. white cow run sky) 
glassy eyes and dazed 
Light sensitivity 
spacing out 
Anyways, my question is how does this happen? What in the brain makes this response happen? I have alice in wonderland syndrome but I take medications. I listed the symptoms of my own time. It is different for each person.


My Journey of thinking started with the Immune system, traveled on to Allergies, and is currently in Migraines.

By: Elizabeth Ashley Irwin At : 2015-01-30 08:24

Hear are some facts on bones that I learned 
* bones heal by the body producing many new cells that cover both ends of the bone until the ends are fused together again 
* there are 7 different types of fractures 
* the worst fractures are called either a comminuted fracture- bone is broken in more than 2 places or shattered, or a open fracture- bone is sticking threw the skin 
* the least bad fracture a kid can get is a bowing fracture- bone bends but doesn't brake 
* the least bad fracture an adult can have is a greenstick fracture- bone is broken on 1 side not all the way threw 
* also sometimes people will pass out, feel dissy, or be cold

Title: Nellie: How does our body react to chemicals?
Text:
MY Journey of Thinking...

At the beginning of the year, I studied blood and the circulatory system. I did his for only a little while because I felt that my thinking was not advancing. My notes were very simple.
Then we did the group research. My question was about bodily chemical reaction. I was then put in a group...
So I moved on to allergies. I enjoyed working on it because it was something I could learn about easily. I did this most of the year. My advanced notes were like this: 
Yes, your DNA and genes have something to do with your allergies, and how you react to them. If one of your parents has an allergy, there is a 30% chance you will have that allergy. If both of your parents have an allergy it is a 70% chance. My theory is that you could also have similar allergic reactions to these allergies compared to your parents.
By January (literally), I was studying migraines. My knowledge advanced because I was researching something I was really interested in. I have migraines personally, and I feel as if I am starting to solve my problems. It gives me a positive feeling. My latest notes have been like this:
I get these massive headaches and they are sharp and they sting. The doctor calls them migraines, phenomenon of the brain. I went to the hospital and they treated me with an I. V. 
My thinking evolved because I thought about what would be of my most interest and of what I am actually experiencing.

Name: Shreya N Mahesh
Title: why exercise is important
Text:
Kids exercise all the time without even thinking of it. Just being active, like when you run around outside or play kickball at school, is a kind of exercise. What else counts as exercise? Playing sports, dancing, doing push-ups, and even reaching down to touch your toes.

When you exercise, you're helping build a strong body that will be able to move around and do all the stuff you need it to do. Try to be active every day and your body will thank you later!

Exercise Makes Your Heart Happy
You may know that your heart is a muscle. It works hard, pumping blood every day of your life. You can help this important muscle get stronger by doing aerobic (say: air-OH-bik) exercise.

Exercise is good for your lungs. Which of these is your favorite?
Biking
Swimming
Dancing
Running
Other:

Vote
View Results
Aerobic means "with air," so aerobic exercise is a kind of activity that requires oxygen. When you breathe, you take in oxygen, and, if you're doing aerobic exercise, you may notice you're breathing faster than normal. Aerobic activity can get your heart pumping, make you sweaty, and quicken your breathing.

When you give your heart this kind of workout on a regular basis, your heart will get even better at its main job \ delivering oxygen (in the form of oxygen-carrying blood cells) to all parts of your body.

So you want to do some aerobic exercise right now? Try swimming, basketball, ice or roller hockey, jogging (or walking quickly), inline skating, soccer, cross-country skiing, biking, or rowing. And don't forget that skipping, jumping rope, and playing hopscotch are aerobic activities, too!

Name: JIANWEI ZHANG
Title: Teacher reflection journaling
Text:
Hi Pat, Stacey, and Tom,

As we've discussed, it'd be helpful to use the scaffolds for reflective noticing and envisioning to sharing our reflections on the inquiry process in each week. Depending on your time and the progress of classroom work, please write 1-2 notes about the knowledge building work in each room. Please select the scaffold set Teacher Noticing and Envisioning and choose scaffold supports that are relevant. I suggest that you begin each week's reflection with the scaffold A Snapshot of the Recent Work, to summarize/highlight the major work of the students. Then you may write about any important going-ons you've noticed and will respond to. When you write about a problem/advance/misconception reflected in a student note, you can add reference to this note.

I hope that this reflection will help each of us individually as well as our learning as a whole team.

Name: Shreya N Mahesh
Title: why exercise is cool
Text:
Kids exercise all the time without even thinking of it. Just being active, like when you run around outside or play kickball at school, is a kind of exercise. What else counts as exercise? Playing sports, dancing, doing push-ups, and even reaching down to touch your toes.

When you exercise, you're helping build a strong body that will be able to move around and do all the stuff you need it to do. Try to be active every day and your body will thank you later!

Exercise Makes Your Heart Happy
You may know that your heart is a muscle. It works hard, pumping blood every day of your life. You can help this important muscle get stronger by doing aerobic (say: air-OH-bik) exercise.

Exercise is good for your lungs. Which of these is your favorite?
Biking
Swimming
Dancing
Running
Other:

Vote
View Results
Aerobic means "with air," so aerobic exercise is a kind of activity that requires oxygen. When you breathe, you take in oxygen, and, if you're doing aerobic exercise, you may notice you're breathing faster than normal. Aerobic activity can get your heart pumping, make you sweaty, and quicken your breathing.

When you give your heart this kind of workout on a regular basis, your heart will get even better at its main job \ delivering oxygen (in the form of oxygen-carrying blood cells) to all parts of your body.

So you want to do some aerobic exercise right now? Try swimming, basketball, ice or roller hockey, jogging (or walking quickly), inline skating, soccer, cross-country skiing, biking, or rowing. And don't forget that skipping, jumping rope, and playing hopscotch are aerobic activities, too!

Exercise Strengthens Muscles
Another kind of exercise can help make your muscles stronger. Did you ever do a push-up or swing across the monkey bars at the playground? Those are exercises that can build strength. By using your muscles to do powerful things, you can make them stronger. For older teens and adults, this kind of workout can make muscles bigger, too.

Here are some exercises and activities to build strong muscles:

push-ups
pull-ups
tug-of-war
rowing
running
inline skating
bike riding

Name: Nellie Grace Cordi
Title: New Study: How Did Humans Learn To Be Civilized?
Text:
I have a very complex theory... here it goes:
During the Ice Age, humans (cave men) had no civilization at all. They lived in caves, banged sticks on the ground, and spent their time chasing wooly mammoths. Very civilized... :-)
Then came the Middle Ages... humans became polite. They learned table manners. In the early 1900s, children were taught very well. QUESTIONS: How did we become polite? How did we learn manners?
Now, children are totally uncivilized. Yes, we all know right from wrong, but do we know when we are acting rude or cruel? I don't believe any of us notice when we feel mad or upset, or when we all are talking and someone gets an opposing response.
---HOW WILL THIS CHANGE HUMANS IN THE FUTURE---
This will make us go into war. We all have seen it on the news very often, and it's not okay. We can't do anything as kids... or can we?
PLEASE help me stiudy, I will need help at certaim points in my research process. Thank you for your time, keep up the well being, and good work, to a fellow mad scientist.
--Nellie Grace

Name: Shreya N Mahesh
Title: why do people exercise?
Text:
Exercise helps keep you fit and strong. It also boosts your energy, reduces stress and helps you feel good. Exercise several times a week that 'raises a sweat' is good but even small amounts can help.
Contents
Why it is important
Starting out
Choosing the right kind
Avoiding injury
The three types of fitness
Don't overdo it
Resources

Why it is important
People are not as active as they used to be and most people need to add exercise into their lives. Being active can make you feel:
Energetic, strong and healthy.
Able to do the 'every-day' activities of your life more easily.
Great - physical activity releases endorphins - these are the body's natural "feel good" chemicals.
Less stressed. Exercise can improve mental health and reduce depression.
Strong. Your muscles become stronger with more physical activity.
Less tired. You'll have a better night's sleep if you are regularly active.
Good about yourself, through better self-esteem and confidence.
You can also make friends through sports.
Any physical activity that involves an impact, eg walking, running, aerobics etc, helps to keep calcium in your bones, keeping them stronger for longer. This will make you stand tall and strong and help prevent osteoporosis when you're older.
Physical activity also means a strong heart and lungs - they'll last longer - and so will you! Exercise can lower your blood pressure and 'bad cholesterol', so you'll stay healthier in later years.

Starting out
It may seem hard at first, but the more you do, the more you will feel like doing.
Start slowly and build up. A very common reason why people don't keep exercising is that they started out doing too much too soon.
Try something new with a friend - it can be fun, and can keep you both motivated.
Do something you enjoy.
If you have had health problems you might want to get a check up before starting a new activity.

Choosing the right kind
Team sports can be a great way of having fun and improving your fitness at the same time. This can be a good way of making new friends.
Some people prefer individual activities that they can do whenever and however they want, such as bike riding, swimming or walking. 
Some people find dance classes a lot of fun.
There are many other activities you can do with a friend anytime, such as walking on the beach, a park or through the bush, having a game of golf or tennis, or swimming. Go roller blading, skate boarding, kick a ball around, or "shoot hoops".
There are holidays built around fun activities like skiing or wild adventure type holidays where you take in white water rafting, canoeing, mountain hiking and abseiling for example. You can also get involved in these kinds of activities on a one-off basis.
Try your local gym - most local gyms and many community centres offer organised fitness classes. You should have finished growing before using weights. Community centres may offer activities such as yoga, tai chi and self defence classes which can be cheaper than gyms.
How much?
At least 60 minutes of physical activity every day is recommended. This can built up throughout the day with a variety of activities. Physical activity should be done at moderate to vigorous intensity.               
Vigorous activities are those that make you "huff and puff". For additional health benefits, try to include 20 minutes or more of vigorous activity at least three to four days a week.

Avoiding injury
Start exercising at a moderate level and build up slowly. Do the training needed so that your muscles are ready for the extra work they need to do.
It is important to do some warm up exercises before you begin. Warming up prepares the body and reduces the chances of getting cramps or serious injuries. Walking, riding an exercise bike, gentle aerobic movements or dancing are good ways of warming up.
Cooling down properly will reduce the risk of muscle soreness or stiffness the next day. You can use the same kinds of physical activities that you used to warm up.
Stretches should be a part of warming up and cooling down.

The three types of fitness
When people talk about fitness, they are usually talking about three types of fitness. These are stamina, strength and flexibility.
Stamina and Endurance
Stamina or endurance refers to the body's ability to do physical activities for long periods of time. Running, dancing, aerobics, ball sports and other exercises that make your heart beat faster and cause you to sweat increase stamina.
Strength and Power
Physical activities that increase strength are called anaerobic activities. Anaerobic activities aim to increase physical strength, power and muscle capacity, allowing you to perform movements such as jumping and sprinting. Strong muscles also support and stabilise bone joints (such as ankles, knees, hips, shoulders and backs), reducing the risk of injury. 
Resistance training is one way to improve power and strength. Examples are push ups and using weights (start with light ones and increase slowly). 
Flexibility and Suppleness
Flexibility and suppleness refers to your body's ability to perform its full range of movements without pain or restriction. If tendons and muscles become tight you are more likely to get injuries such as pulled or strained muscles and joint soreness. Gentle stretching will improve flexibility.

Don't overdo it
If you are spending a lot of time exercising, you may be overdoing it, which can be harmful to your health and often a cause of serious injuries.
Pain is a sign that you have worked too hard or have an injury ? take notice of it and cut back on how hard you are working or change the activity until the injury has healed. A bit of stiffness and soreness after working hard can be normal, but pain that is severe or which lasts more than a couple of days is a sign of an injury.
Some people push drugs called steroids, saying they can make you fitter, stronger and faster. Taking steroids can be dangerous and have serious side effects. Many drugs are illegal for sports players. For more information look at the Sport Medicine Australia 'Cleanedge'  website.

Resources
South Australia
The Office for Recreation and Sport website 
http://www.recsport.sa.gov.au/
Disability, Recreation and Sports SA 
http://www.drssa.org.au/
Australia
The Better Health Channel , a website providing health and medical information supported by the State Government of Victoria.
http://www.betterhealth.vic.gov.au/bhcv2/bhcarticles.nsf/pages/Exercise_safety

The information on this site should not be used as an alternative to professional care. If you have a particular problem, see a doctor, or ring the Youth Healthline on 1300 13 17 19 (local call cost from anywhere in South Aus

Name: Patricia Gagnon
Title: BODY IMAGING
Text:
we had a great conversation today about the variety of ways doctors can look inside our bodies to help determine what is wrong.
There are:
MRI;  magnetic resonance imaging which uses magnets to look at soft tissues like brain and spinal cord, or blood vessels
x-rays for looking at bones
ultrasounds using sound waves to image soft tissues.
NG tube stands for nasogastric tube used down the nose and into the stomach .
We have come a long way from having to look into an open wound to see how the stomach works like the Dr. Beaumont(sp?)
The benefit of these tools is they are NONINVASIVE which means they do not break the skin and open the body to infection or extra bleeding.
What more can you add to this thinking?

Name: Sareena Gurung
Title: Different parts of the brain
Text:
Cerebrum-Keeps our memories and controls how we respond to different sensory signals from the world around us.

Cerebellum-Coordinates all of your movement and muscles to walk or run and remain balanced.

Frontal Lobe-Controls our ability to use word and speech and also how we react emotionally.

Parietal Lobe-Controls our sense of touch and also controls our hands to complete tasks.

Occipital Lobe-Controls our vision.

Temporal Lobe-Controls hearing and our ability to organize things.

Pons-Controls breathing and heart beat

Brain Stem-Sends all of the decisions that the brain makes to the rest of the body

Title: Allergies affecting the immune system
Text:
When the immune system does not function properly, it leaves the body susceptible to an array of diseases. Allergies and hypersensitivity to certain substances are considered immune system disorders. In addition, the immune system plays a role in the rejection process of transplanted organs or tissue. Other examples of immune system disorders include:
Cancer of the Immune System
Autoimmune Disease  
Juvenile Diabetes 
Rheumatoid 
Arthritis
Anemia
Immune Complex Diseases
Viral Hepatitis and Malaria 
Immunodeficiency Disease 
Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome (AIDS)

Title: tongue
Text:
Your tongue is very important to you. The tongue helps shove food down your throat for you to swallow. Your tongue also mixes saliva with food to help it digest and makes it easier to swallow. Your tongue also refines the sound your vocal chords make to create complex sounds and speech.
      


      Your tongue has many uses. Even though some people think it is near useless, it isn't. try speaking without your tongue. It's hard! Try eating without it. Don't underestimate it, because you need it.

Name: Senbahavalli Rajalakshmi Ramasamy
Title: Asthma
Text:
Asthma is a special condition that affects the way a person breathes. 

People with Asthma breath normally most of the time, but during and Asthma flare-up,it can get a little hard to breathe.

The airways, or tubes go into the lungs, and then they get swollen. The airways get narrower, so it is harder for the air to move out of the tubes. The airways also make more mucus, which is the sticky stuff that coats the tubes.

During an Asthma flare-up, a person might cough or wheeze, which means breathing with a whistling sound. The person also might feel a tightness in the chest. When that happens, people use an inhaler during an Asthma flare-up to help them feel better. (Did you know that medicine in the inhaler can work pretty fast, and it can make your body health again).

Trigger
Something that causes an asthma flare-up

People with different types of asthma, have different tigers, like
Exercise
Pet Hair
Plants 
Dust

Strong smells like cigarette smoke or perfume can also trigger asthma attacks

Sometimes, 
Laughing to Hard 
Yelling 
Crying
Can also tigger flare-ups for some people with asthma too. Some people get asthma attacks every once in a while and other people get them more often.

Asthma is not contagious and you can't catch if any one has asthma.

Name: Senbahavalli Rajalakshmi Ramasamy
Title: Lungs
Text:
Lungs
Organs inside your chest that helps you breath.

The lungs are part of the respiratory system which is in charge of breathing.

Inhale
Breathing in air through your nose or mouth

Fresh air rushes down your windpipe, or trachea. The diaphragm, a muscle under your lungs, and that helps bring air into your lungs. Your diaphragm moves down your ribcage, so it pushes out so your lungs have space to fill up air. 

The lungs take oxygen out of the air and into your blood. Your heart pumps the blood through out the body because every part needs oxygen.

Exhale 
Breath out through your nose or mouth

Your diaphragm helps push air out of the lungs. Your ribcage pulls in tighter and that helps push out stuff your body does not really need like the gas, Carson dioxide.

Lungs help you talk. As air pushes out of your lungs, it goes past the vocal chords in you throat. Then the vocal chords make sounds. Your lungs can also help you,
Sing
Laugh
Shout 
Cry
Your lung can help you communicate.

Your diaphragm and lungs help you sneeze to get rid of that tv others that airways in your body.

Name: Joshua Walter Matthews
Title: smoking
Text:
Tobacco use is the leading preventable cause of death.
Worldwide, tobacco use causes more than 5 million deaths per year, and current trends show that tobacco use will cause more than 8 million deaths annually by 2030.2
Cigarette smoking is responsible for more than 480,000 deaths per year in the United States, including an estimated 41,000 deaths resulting from secondhand smoke exposure.1 This is about one in five deaths annually, or 1,300 deaths every day.1
On average, smokers die 10 years earlier than nonsmokers.3
If smoking persists at the current rate among youth in this country, 5.6 million of todayfs Americans younger than 18 years of age are projected to die prematurely from a smoking-related illness. This represents about one in every 13 Americans aged 17 years or younger who are alive today.1

Name: Manager Manager
Title: The number of key words
Text: Hi Alexa, I had thought to talk with you about this problem in the class. However, I haven't seen you since last Wednesday. There might be a limit on the number of key words for searching the KF notes. Because every time the searching engine will do the job separately. If you input three key words in the box, the searching engine will search all notes related to each word. The more keywords you have, the heavier the workload will be. I guess that might be a reason for it, especially when all your classmates are working on it. So my suggestion is that you can search one or two words each time. Meanwhile, we are trying our best to improve the performance of ITM. Hopefully it will solve this problem soon. Sorry about that. And thanks for your question. -Dan

Title: Urinary system
Text: It all starts in the kidneys. The kidneys are like strainers. They only let water and wast pass through the nephrons. The  water and wast make urine also known as pee. The  urine (pee) trickles into the orators, the tubes connected from the kidneys and the bladder. The urine travels through the orators to the bladder. The bladder fills up like a balloon, in till it realizes the urine. The urine goes down a tube called the urethra. Then the nerves send a message to the brain saying I have to go to the bathroom.

Title: Bones
Text: Bones are made from living cells, blood vessels, and nerves. A bone is hard on the outside but is soft and spongy inside. This makes bones very strong but also light and flexible. Name: Nellie Grace Cordi
Title: Information on the Ice Age
Text:
The first appearance of man was as a tool using mammal. The Stone Age is divided into three separate periods: Paleolithic, Mesolithic, and Neolithic. This was based on how sophisticated the tools humans used were. The oldest recognizable tools were found during this time. They call it the Pleistocene Age. Momentous climatic events occurred.

During the Paleolithic, humans gathered food, hunted animals, and collecting wild fruits, vegetables, and nuts. Tools were made of flint, stone, bone, and antler. Things went from simple to complex.

The tools were called: pebble, bifacial or hand-ax, flake, and blade.

STONE AGE DEFINITION: prehistoric cultural stage, or level of human development, characterized by the creation and use of the first tools.

FUN FACT: Ice Age weather patterns will make a new Ice Age in thousands of years, but it may be warmer than the last Ice Age because of Global Warming and Earth Pollution.

--Nellie

Name: Nicholas P Darrigo
Title: Spinal Cord
Text: Your spinal cord is an extension of the brain stem. It is made of of neuron buckles that carry impulses to your body and brain. A canal goes through the center of your spinal cord. It sends special fluids that provide nourishment to the cord cells, and acts as a shock absorber for the impulses.

Name: George Qu
Title: The eyes and perception
Text:
___________________________What is color? ____________________________
What we see as color is actually a part of the electromagnet spectrum. Parts of the spectrum is what what our brains perceive as "colors". The part of the spectrum goes in your cornea, gets focused into the pupil, iris, an lens. Then it goes onto the retina, which senses the part of the spectrum as "color.  There are only 3 types of "color" receptors in the retina, green, red, and yellow. However, many types of spectrum parts can trigger different types of receptors at the same time, causing a color mix, sort of like mixing colors in art. The retina "translates" the detected part of the spectrum into electric signals, which goes into the brain. The brain perceives the signals into "color".
      But does one brain actually perceive color the same as another brain?
Would my green be your yellow? What is true perception? What is correct perception? Is there even correct perception? Will scientists ever find out?

        Will there ever be an answer to this? I don't think so. But if you find out something that might be close to the an answer, please build on to this.

Name: George Qu
Title: genetics
Text: inheritance
column8: and possibly the answer to color blindness
column9:
I think I might know the answer to what causes colorblindness.

I read a lot of articles about colorblindness. A lot of them state that colorblindness is inherited from parents. Traits from parents are passed on by genetics, and DNA. 
  So what does this mean? 

  Colorblindness is a mutation.

 Because colorblindness can be passed on, it is likely that it is caused by DNA. However, most people aren't colorblind. Could colorblindness be a mutation?  Probably . Here's another theory.

 The "colorblind people" are "normal".

 As Christian theorized  , " but this sounds crazy maybe, just maybe colorblind people are the regular people." At first I was skeptical, and so was James, and then I thought about this. Could this be true? Could this be a part of evolution? Have humans evolved to see color? This might be true. But if this was so, could there be another sensation right under our nose that we can't sense? 

   We don't know...
                             ...yet
  
    Thanks for reading. If you have a theory that might solve this, please build-on to this note.

Name: Isabella Grace Audino
Title: Respiratory System
Text:
The human respiratory system is a series of organs responsible for taking in oxygen and expelling carbon dioxide. The primary organs of the respiratory system are lungs, which carry out this exchange of gases as we breathe.

Red blood cells collect the oxygen from the lungs and carry it to the parts of the body where it is needed, according to the American Lung Association. During the process, the red blood cells collect the carbon dioxide and transport it back to the lungs, where it leaves the body when we exhale

Name: John Francis Giordano
Title: windpipe
Text: a tube in your neck called the windpipe carries air to the lungs until they're full and you can't take in any more air.  you can only hold your breath for a little bit and we breathe carbon dioxide out.  we can breathe automatically.  that means we breathe without even thinking about it.  It can be very important that we breathe automatically because we breathe when we are sleeping.  when we breathe out ,carbon dioxide enters a nearby capillary.  Blood in the capillary picks up the carbon dioxide and begins the return trip to the heart.  carrying carbon dioxide the blood travels through blood vessels called veins.  the veins deliver  blood to the heart,which pumps it to the lungs.  in the lungs the carbon dioxide leaves the blood by passing through the wall of a capillary.  and and into the lungs tiny air sacks.when we exhale wwe breathe out carbon dioxide then the whole process starts all over again.

Name: Vicky Lin
Title: asthma
Text:
Asthma (AZ-ma) is a chronic (long-term) lung disease that inflames and narrows the airways. Asthma causes recurring periods of wheezing (a whistling sound when you breathe), chest tightness, shortness of breath, and coughing. The coughing often occurs at night or early in the morning.         
Quoted at http://www.nhlbi.nih.gov/health/health-topics/topics/asthma

Name: Eric Yukun Cao
Title: DNA's best friend
Text:
There is another nucleic acid known as RNA, which acts as a messenger. RNA only has one strand, while DNA is a double helix.
There are two types of RNA.
Messenger RNA copies the DNA in the nucleus, then carries the information outside of the nucleus to the ribosomes.
 Transfer RNA carries amino acids to the ribosome for assembly into proteins.
DNA is like the brain of a cell it controls what the cell is meant to do for example if a cell were meant to make proteins for our body the DNA of the cell would know what to do.

Name: Vicky Lin
Title: asthma
Text:
Asthma (AZ-ma) is a chronic (long-term) lung disease that inflames and narrows the airways. Asthma causes recurring periods of wheezing (a whistling sound when you breathe), chest tightness, shortness of breath, and coughing. The coughing often occurs at night or early in the morning.

Asthma affects people of all ages, but it most often starts during childhood. In the United States, more than 25 million people are known to have asthma. About 7 million of these people are children.
Quote http://www.nhlbi.nih.gov/health/health-topics/topics/asthma

Name: Alexa Madison Gabor
Title: dominant and recessive hair
Text:
Everyone has two hair genes. Dominant hair colours are black and brown and recessive are blonde and red. To be born with a dominant hair colour, both your parents have to have two dominant genes. If they have a black/blonde and black/black hair genes you'll get black hair.

If the parents have recessive/dominant and recessive/dominant you can get either, but if it's recessive/ dominant and recessive/recessive you'll get blonde or red hair. Also if you get for recessive genes you have a chance at all of them.

Title: How Nomads became Natives and much much more!
Text:
If you like Minecraft, especially survival, you'll LOVE this...
Natives started farming. They cold stay in one place, so they were no longer nomads (travelers). They had time to build stronger houses, and formed small communities Population grew, so each person could focus on his or her own job.
If you have played Minecraft, its kind of like that, except instead of being pixelated, its in real life. If you find a village, they have a farm or garden, a blacksmith, a chapel, a library, (these were not in existence yet, only in minecraft, which didn't exist either :D ) and a well for water. There were also extra houses scattered around for healers, hunters, gardeners, (librarians :D lol ) gatherers, and weavers. They have plenty of villagers who own chests. They store food in them and other valuables like string for weaving.
Keep looking for more posts on my friends who are being civilized now!!!!!!!

Name: James David Kelly IV
Title: excerpt from Light and Color
Text: Light travels in the form of a wave. It is basically photons (pieces of energy or particles), and mostly moves as waves. White light, or the light from the sun, is made of colors, and colors are different types of light recognized by their own wavelengths. Waves exist above and below the visible spectrum, too. Such waves called radio, microwave, and infrared are below the red end of the spectrum, and ultraviolet (UV), x-rays, and gamma rays are above the violet. These cannot be seen by the human eye, and therefore constitute the "invisible" spectrum. Together, the visible and invisible spectrums make up the electromagnetic spectrum.

Name: Toby Joseph Thomas
Title: Urinary system
Text:
.  The urinary system is one part of your body's excretory system. 

. The urinary system removes poison called urea from the bloodstream.

. Inside the kidneys little filters called nephrons.

. From the kidneys, urine goes from small tubes called urethras and it empties to the bladder.
. The kidneys send a little bit of urine to the bladder every 10 seconds.
.Circular muscles called sphincters keep the urine leaking out the bladder's opening

Name: Nellie Grace Cordi
Title: How has human civilization changed over time?
Text:
How did this make the world a better place? How does this affect humans? How did humans learn to be civilized?
Very good questions. I was just wondering, what do you think of my research? Please post as a build on to the last person's note on my 'stairway of thinking'. 
So, here it is...
  THE EVOLUTION OF HUMAN CIVILIZATION!!!!!!!!!!
Stone Age means a prehistoric, culture-filled stage, or level of human development, characterized by the creation and use of stone tools. Humans used these tools later on.
This was the beginning of an EPOCH. This means phase, and is said e-poke. This epoch was the Pleistocene era.
Some facts for you...
-sometimes called Quaternary
- is pronounced Play- stow- scene
Animal species were wiped out by a giant flood, the Continental Drift. This not only formed continents, but broke the land bridge, so that you could no longer travel from Asia to Alaska and Canada. Luckily, humans were already on this side of the ocean, and survived. Why? Because they were intelligent and adaptable.
There were jobs during their Nomadic travels. Gatherers collected special fruits, hunters chased wild boar and other animals, and healers doctored the people who were sick or infected with a disease. Soon we were on our way.
AGRICULTURE means things that adapt to help us stay alive.
People soon made tools to hunt and nets to fish. They began forest gardening, which was easier, but you often stumbled upon something poisonous, making the healer that much more busy. The nomads traveled in troops.
People made baskets and pots for necessities. They developed a religion around multiple gods. They got settled in one area, right around anywhere in the North America area. They were no longer nomads, but natives, being that they did not travel.
So the Natives formed little towns, like the early Mayans, and began farming. This helped them to grow food to eat, and trade with other small communities. They built stronger homes, and developed larger towns. Members of these groups could now focus on one job they could do well, and were now civilized.

I really hoped you enjoyed learning. Don't forget to build on! Now time for some research...

Name: Elizabeth Ashley Irwin
Title: Kinematics
Text:
For people who don't know what kinematics are they are a form of mechanics that describe a moving object in three ways: Position, velocity, and acceleration.( Also this is mostly referring to ice hockey)
 Position: The position part of kinematics refers to the location of the player on the ice at a given moment. 
 Velocity: The velocity part of kinematics has 2 parts. 1, the players speed. 2, the players direction. An example of why this is part is if a player is going a distance of 64 ft, at a speed of 2.3 secs to go this distance, you can divide the number of feet by the number of seconds to find out that the player went an average speed of 27.83ft per sec.
 Acceleration: The acceleration part of kinematics refers to the change in a players speed/direction over a period of time. Example: if a player has a velocity of 23 ft per sec and an acceleration time of 1.4 secs,  then the players average acceleration is 16.43 ft per sec per sec.

Name: Alexa Madison Gabor
Title: Schizophrenia-the truth
Text: Schizophrenia (pronounced skit-zo-fren-ia) is a brain disorder that affects roughly 1% of the population. That being said, it's extremely rare. It is also mostly genetic. This brain disorder causes it's victim to have auditory hallucinations, or hear voices. The voices are very negative and criticize or insult the victim. Sometimes, they're are reassuring. Saying things like "Don't worry" or "It'll be alright". They make it very hard to concentrate on things like, tests, papers, or homework. Oftentimes the victim may not want to socialize with other people, and just start a conversation with their auditory hallucinations. Sometimes they'll even have names for them. Sometimes the voices may tell them to do something bad, like hurt themselves or other people. Victims may also experience visual hallucinations. Luckily, there's medicines for people with schizophrenia. Schizophrenia is one of the most serious brain disorder. It causes people to withdrawal from their friends or family, or seriously hurt themselves or other people. Though there is no cure, there is medicine to help people with schizophrenia live happy and healthy lives.

Name: Alexa Madison Gabor
Title: People making light of mental disorders (THIS IS A LARGE NOTE BUT INTERESTING)
Text:
Some people try to make light of brain/mental disorders like schizophrenia, psychopathy (sy-cop-path-y), depression, Bipolar Disorder, anxiety disorders and OCD. They don't fully understand what it's like for the people who have to live with these disorders. You've probably heard someone say that something is "schizophrenic" because it's paranoid (paranoia is a big symptom of schizophrenia), that their next-door neighbor is a "psychopath", that they're so depressed that their favourite store closed down, or that they're "so OCD" (which doesn't make sense because you're saying "you're so obsessive compulsive disorder"). I'll take a look of the truth about the mental disorders. Let's start with the big one: OCD.

OCD (Obsessive-Compulsive disorder) is a mental disorder classified of intense fears or anxieties "obsessions" and rituals or processes to get rid of the fear "compulsions". A common compulsion is frequently washing your hands, switching off a light a certain amount of times, or opening and closing a door repeatedly. Despite popular beliefs, OCD ISN'T being super tidy. OCD is classified as an anxiety disorder, but there are subtypes of OCD like dermotillomania (Picking of the skin) and trichotillomania (pulling out hair) to relieve anxieties. Not everyone has "a touch of OCD" because it (like all anxiety disorders) only affect abut 30% of the population. 

Next I'll explain another big one: psychopathy. Besides OCD, psychopathy is probably the most misunderstood mental disorder. Plenty of people have probably called someone a "psychopath" for acting insane. Psychopathy is a serious mental disorder which the victim will do whatever (s)he wants, regardless of the consequence. Victims will have no empathy, even to their close friends or family. They can seriously hurt another person and not care about the consequence or the people around him/her. So you see, a "psychopath" would not be your crazy next door neighbor, but a person with an extremely dangerous and serious mental disorder. Luckily there is medicines and help for psychopathy.
 
Next is depression. Depression is the most common mental disorder but often misunderstood. Many people say that they're "depressed" that their favourite show just ended, or that their favourite food is out of stock, without really knowing what they're saying. Despite being the most common, depression is very serious. A depressed person will stop feeling happy and can't find joy in even their favourite things. They'll start to lose interest in things normally they love to do, because they no longer find any joy in it. They will feel misunderstood,and like they're going through this alone. Untreated depression for long periods of time can result in horrible things like self-harm or suicide. Depression can be genetic or caused by something like a friend or loved one dying. Bipolar Disorder can also cause Depression, as well as disorders like Sensory Processing Disorder going untreated. Also anxiety disorders can cause Depression going untreated. Next I'll talk about Bipolar Disorder.

Bipolar Disorder (formerly Manic-Depressive Disorder), is a neurological disorder caused by an imbalance of chemicals in the brain. People who have bipolar disorder will go through "manic-depressive episodes" which can last a few days or a few weeks. A type of episode is a "manic episode", where they'll experience "Mania". Mania makes one feel on top of the world, like they're invincible and nothing can happen to them. You probably see the problem in this, because they might take dangerous risks. They'll seem very very antsy and excited for no particular reason, and they'll have a hard time sitting still. Manic episodes are usually referred to as a "High" of bipolar disorder. After a High there must be a Low. The low of bipolar disorder is "depressive episodes" Hence the name, the person will experience "Bipolar Depression". As stated in the depression paragraph, there is all the same symptoms except lasting for less time, and usually followed by a high. Usually a person with bipolar disorder gets medicine for it. They can also go to therapy to help them cope with highs and lows.
 
Anxiety disorders are a group of mental illnesses (they include, General anxiety disorder, obsessive-compulsive disorder, Post-traumatic stress disorder, panic disorder, separation anxiety, social anxiety, and Phobia Disorders). Anxiety disorders are fairly common but still a minority, since it affects only 30% of the population. Anxiety is different than fear, since fear is something you feel when confronted with something, but anxiety is worries about something that might happen. Anxiety disorders aren't diagnosed (like all mental illnesses) until the anxiety is affecting how you live your normal life. Anxious people are constantly worrying about things very irrational, mostly things that will never happen. It becomes the only thing they can think about, and they can not shake themselves away from this feeling that something is going to happen. Severe anxiety may result in the person not able to leave their own house. Anxiety is commonly misdiagnosed as ADD, ADHD, and ODD because it makes a person antsy and irritable. Untreated anxiety may result in depression. 

In conclusion, mental illnesses are not something to make light of. So next time you say you're "so depressed" about your favourite show, or that someone is acting like a "psychopath", think of the millions of people living with these horrible illnesses. Try to take into mind what they're going through, and think before you say. Anyone with any of these disorders would gladly switch places with you. And remember, these are real illnesses. OCD isn't "all in your head" and depressed people can't just "be happy". Telling an anxious person to just think of something else or depressed person to be happy is like telling a crippled person to get up and walk. In addition, try not to think of a person as their illness. Instead of calling someone a "schizophrenic" say that they "have schizophrenia". Instead of calling someone a "psychopath", just say that they "have psychopathy". Thank you for reading this tiny article!

Name: George Qu
Title: DNA and chromosomes
Text: Chromosomes are bundles of DNA. The chromosomes are proteins wrapped around DNA. These chromosomes are essential to organisms and important to traits of humans or any living organisms. Chromosomes are in cells and are the rules for what the cell does. A cell needs to divide to stay alive and it lets your body grow. At the end of a chromosome, there is a thing called a telomere. The telomere keeps information in DNA safe. Every time a cell divides, the telomeres get worn down a little more. When the telomeres are gone, the organism dies.
