Example: 
 When on a spinning chair start spinning. In the beginning spred your arms out wide, then quickly pull your arms in. You will notice that you start going faster. Now put your arms out wide again. You will slow down. This happens because of angular momentum.

 Smaller body position = FASTER

Title: pain
Text:
Pain can can come in a lot of different forms, from getting a cut to crushing a bone.  Pain is not a bad thing it's your body's reaction to protect the cut or break while it's healing.  It tells you if something is messing with your wound pain tells you to pull your arm away. 
    pain doesn't just travel from the point of pain to the spine, it travels through many nervous systems then to the spine and brain.
    Acute pain happens more often and lasts for a short amount of time. It's like stubbing your toe or getting a shot.  On the other hand chronic pain lasts for a long time and hurts a lot more.  Chronic pain is most likely to happen in painful conditions such as cancer, arthritis ect.  Thermal and mechanical pain are very unlikely to happen but are super painful.  It is crushing, tearing or shearing a ligament or bone.

Name: Christian Andrew Jahnel
Title: Bee article
Text:
A bumblebee visits a flower, drawn in by the bright colours, the patterns on the petals, and the aromatic promise of sweet nectar. But therefs more to pollination than sight and smell. There is also electricity in the air.

Dominic Clarke and Heather Whitney from the University of Bristol have shown that bumblebees can sense the electric field that surrounds a flower. They can even learn to distinguish between fields produced by different floral shapes, or use them to work out whether a flower has been recently visited by other bees. Flowers arenft just visual spectacles and smelly beacons. Theyfre also electric billboards.

gThis is a big finding,h says Daniel Robert, who led the study. gNobody had postulated the idea that bees could be sensitive to the electric field of a flower.h

Scientists have, however, known about the electric side of pollination since the 1960s, although it is rarely discussed. As bees fly through the air, they bump into charged particles from dust to small molecules. The friction of these microscopic collisions strips electrons from the beefs surface, and they typically end up with a positive charge.

Flowers, on the other hand, tend to have a negative charge, at least on clear days. The flowers themselves are electrically earthed, but the air around them carries a voltage of around 100 volts for every metre above the ground. The positive charge that accumulates around the flower induces a negative charge in its petals.

When the positively charged bee arrives at the negatively charged flower, sparks donft fly but pollen does. gWe found some videos showing that pollen literally jumps from the flower to the bee, as the bee approachesc even before it has landed,h says Robert. The bee may fly over to the flower but at close quarters, the flower also flies over to the bee.

This is old news. As far back as the 1970s, botanists suggested that electric forces enhance the attraction between pollen and pollinators. Some even showed that if you sprinkle pollen over an immobilised bee, some of the falling grains will veer off course and stick to the insect.

But Robert is no botanist. Hefs a sensory biologist. He studies how animals perceive the world around them. When he came across the electric world of bees and flowers, the first question that sprang to mind was: gDoes the bee know anything about this process?h Amazingly, no one had asked the question, much less answered it. gWe read all of the papers,h says Robert. gWe even had one translated from Russian, but no one had made that intellectual leap.h

To answer the question, Robert teamed up with Clarke (a physicist) and Whitney (a botanist), and created e-flowers\artificial purple-topped blooms with designer electric fields. When bumblebees could choose between charged flowers that carried a sugary liquid, or charge-less flowers that yielded a bitter one, they soon learned to visit the charged ones with 81 percent accuracy. If none of the flowers were charged, the bees lost the ability to pinpoint the sugary rewards.

But the bees can do more than just tell if an electric field is there or not. They can also discriminate between fields of different shapes, which in turn depend on the shape of a flowerfs petals and how easily they conduct electricity. Clarke and Whitney visualised these patterns by spraying flowers with positively charged and brightly coloured particles. You can see the results below. Each flower has been sprayed on its right half, and the rectangular boxes show the colours of the particles.The bees can sense these patterns. They can learn to tell the difference between an e-flower with an evenly spread voltage and one with a field like a bullseye with 70 percent accuracy.

Bees can also use this electric information to bolster what their other senses are telling them. The team trained bees to discriminate between two e-flowers that came in very slightly different shades of green. They managed it, but it took them 35 visits to reach an accuracy of 80 percent. If the team added differing electric fields to the flowers, the bees hit the same benchmark within just 24 visits.

How does the bee actually register electric fields? No one knows, but Robert suspects that the fields produce small forces that move some of the beefs body parts, perhaps the hairs on its body. In the same way that a rubbed balloon makes you hair stand on end, perhaps a charged flower provides a bee with detectable tugs and shoves.

The bees, in turn, change the charge of whatever flower they land upon. Robertfs team showed that the electrical potential in the stem of a petunia goes up by around 25 millivolts when a bee lands upon it. This change starts just before the bee lands, which shows that itfs nothing to do with the insect physically disturbing the flower. And it lasts for just under two minutes, which is longer than the bee typically spends on its visit.

This changing field can tell a bee whether a flower has been recently visited, and might be short of nectar. Itfs like a sign that says gClosed for business. Be right back.h Itfs also a much more dynamic signal than more familiar ones like colour, patterns or smells. All of these are fairly static. Flowers can change them, but it takes minutes or hours to do so. Electric fields, however, change instantaneously whenever a bees lands. They not only provide useful information, but they do it immediately.

Robert thinks that these signals could either be honest or dishonest, depending on the flower. Those that carpet a field and require multiple visits from pollinators will evolve to be truthful, because they cannot afford to deceive their pollinators.  Bees are good learners and if they repeatedly visit an empty flower, they will quickly avoid an entire patch. Worse still, theyfll communicate with their hive-mates, and the entire colony will seek fresh pastures. gIf the flower can signal that it is momentarily empty, then the bee will benefit and the flower will communicate honestly its mitigated attraction,h says Robert.

But some flowers, like tulips or poppies, only need one or two visits to pollinate themselves.  gThese could afford to lie,h says Robert. He expects that they will do everything possible to keep their electric charge constant, even if a bee lands upon them. They should always have their signs flipped to gOpenh. Robertfs students will be testing this idea in the summer.

Many animals can sense electric fields, including sharks and rays, electric fish, at least one species of dolphin, and the platypus. But this is the first time that anyone has discovered this sense in an insect. And in the humble bumblebee, no less! Bees and flowers have been studied intensely for decades, maybe centuries, and it turns out that theyfve been exchanging secret messages all this time.

Now, Robertfs team is going to take their experiments from the lab into the field, to see just how electrically sensitive wild bees can be, and how their senses change according to the weather. gWe are probably only seeing the tip of the electrical iceberg here,h he says.

Name: Hailey Kay Parker
Title: Color: Eye Vison Experiment
Text:
I know that we see the waves that fall in the spectrum called visible light.  Our eyes see different wavelengths of visible light as color.  The main colors we see are red, orange, yellow, green, blue, indigo, and violet.  People can see thousands and thousands of different colors. The cones in your eyes help you see color. 

I need to understand if people see shades of the same color differently.

I think that the yellow might be easier to see different shades of color than the Red And Blue 

Yellow, red, blue, and Green food coloring
4 jars
water

 I labeled 4 jars A,B,C,D then put water and food coloring in each jar , but each jar had a different number of drops. 
Example: for the color green I put 2 drops in A, 4 drops in B, 1 drop in C, and 3 drops in D and asked my classmates to sort the jars from lightest shade to the darkest shade.


 
Green: 7 out of 13 people sorted Green correctly.

Red; 11 out of 12 people sorted Red correctly .

Yellow: 4 out of 12 people sorted Yellow correctly.

Blue:9 out of 12 people sorted Blue correctly 




Green and Yellow were the lightest colors and they were the hardest to sort the different shades. The lighter the color the harder the shades of that color are to sort.
Red and Blue were the darker colors and they were the easiest to sort. The darker the color the easier it is to see the different shades.

If the colors are darker than you can see the different shades of that color easier  but if the color is lighter then its harder to sort the different shades.

Were ushly ice molecules don't vibrate up and down as fast as they do in the quasi-fluid layer because the ice is a solid figure. So the molecules don't move as much.

Name: Natalie Rose Moffre
Title: Down Syndrome affects
Text: Kids with Down Syndrome usually have an upward slant to the eyes, and small ears. Kids with Down Syndrome also might have low muscle tone. Although this might change over time. Kids with Down Syndrome also tend to be smaller. For infants ,low muscle tone may contribute to sucking and feeding problems, as well as digestive issues. Kids with Down syndrome may have delays in speech and self-care skills.

Name: Elizabeth Ashley Irwin
Title: Ice
Text:
This note is about the ice used when you ice skate, figure skate, speed skate, or play hockey. 
   Originally people thought that the reason the ice was slippery was because when you put pressure on the skate blade it melted the ice a little. Though now I have found out that really the ice is slippery because of the top layer of ice that is one molecule thick that is called the quasi-fluid layer vibrates up and down at really high speeds which lets the skate blade go over it almost effortlessly. 
   Also the different skating events have different ice temperatures. Though all of the ice skating events have ice that is one inch thick the ice for speed skating is 21oF were the ice for figure skating and ice hockey is 23oF, this is because the ice for speed skating gets very beat up when you skate on the same ice over and over so they put water on the ice and it has to freeze fast so there is a level playing field. Where in figure skating they have the entire ice rink to skate on. Also in hockey there are intermissions between each mach wear the officials re-do the ice rink.

Name: Bailey Ashtin Yerdon
Title: memory experiment
Text:
Existing Knowledge: We know that the cerebellum is the part of the brain that helps you remember things. Also know as memory. 
Our Question:  How much memory can your cerebellum hold?
Our Hypothesis: The more objects there is the harder it is to remember.
Materials:  Cards
Procedures: We put out 3 cards and let our volenteer memorise the cards for 10 seconds.  Then we had them face the clock and say the cards in the same order they saw them in.  Then we kept adding more card to see how many they could remember.

Name: Nicholas P Darrigo
Title: Myelin
Text:
Myelin is a layer or sheath that wraps around an axon to speed up the signals through the nervous system. Myelin is made of with membranes that shield the axon underneath. A membrane is an outer cover of a cell.  The insulation from the membranes allows the signals to go faster.
Demyelination is when myelin is worn away or damaged and the nerves don't work as well. Causes of this can be inflammation, infection with certain viruses, metabolic problems, loss of oxygen, and physical compression. Metabolic disorders occur when abnormal chemical reactions in your body disrupt metabolism. Metabolism is the process your body uses to get or make energy from food. Myelin is a very important part of the nervous system.

Title: Parts of an Lung Experiment
Text:
The lungs are organs in your body. An organ called the diaphragm makes the lungs expand and deflate.

How does the diaphragm assist the lungs to expand and deflate

I predict that the air pushes the diaphragm out and also the ribcage

The Materials I used was:
Half of a big soda bottle( use the top part of the bottle)
A balloon
2 rubber bands( one big one and one small one)
2 big cut pieces of a shopping bag

1: put the balloon through the bottom of the bottle
2: put the lip of the balloon over the top of the bottle 
3: then put the 2 cut pieces of the shopping bags over the bottom of the bottle
4: put the 2 rubber over the 2 cut pieces shopping bags

The results of my experiment is when the diaphragm expands because the air is pushing the diaphragm out, as well as the ribcage ( my prediction was right)

The diaphragm expands the lungs because the air pushes the diaphragm out when you breathe in, and when you breathe out, the diaphragm and lungs wiil deflate

Title: ILLUSION
Text:
Existing Knowledge I know that your eyes sense light and dark images. These images reach the brain but optical illusion fools the brain.
My Question I wonder how fast my classmates can identify illusions.
My Hypothesis My guess is that it takes 30 seconds or 1 minute to see the illusion.
Materials I will use a laptop and a classmate.
Procedures I follow these steps, I sit at my desk with a computer, ask a person to try my test.
Results Ian Zhang: 0 second, Toby Thomas: 10 seconds, Inanc Ozbay: 15 seconds, Joshua Jerome: 25 seconds, Ryan Schwartz: 35 seconds
Conclusion I found out that some people practice and so it's 0-20 seconds for some people and 30 seconds to 1 minute for some people.

Name: Inanc Isa Ozbay
Title: how does the heal?
Text:
how does the bone heal?

 step1
    After a bone is broken immediately a blood clot and callus from around it.
 step2
    New"threads"of bone cells start to grow on both sides of the bones.
  step3 
    Eventually the fracture closes up and the callus is absorbed by the new cells  this process  may take from six weeks to a year depending were the bone is broken.

Name: Brian Patrick Govin
Title: Bacteria experiment
Text:
>
 We know that bacteria is everywhere, on door knobs, kitchen sink, money, remotes, your skin.  Bacteria grows in places that people touch and use.  There are different types of bacteria.  Bacteria can grow inside your body and make you sick, it can multiply and mutate adapting to your bodies defenses so that it cannot be killed by the white blood cells.  Some bacteria can help you because it can fight off other bacteria and strengthen your body's defenses.

 
  Which locations around the school will have the most bacteria on them:  door handle, laptop keyboard, bathroom toilet handle, classroom water fountain handle, lunch count pen?    Will wiping each location with a disinfectant wipe change the amount of bacteria?


 We believe that the door handle and the laptop keyboard will have the most bacteria present.  We think that wiping the location with disinfectant wipes will kill most of the bacteria, but some bacteria might still grow.



 10 sterile petri dishes
  nutrient agar in each dish
  10 Q-tips for gathering samples
  Lysol disinfectant wipes



1)  wipe each location 3 times with the Q-tip, then rub the Q-tip across the petri dish with nutrient agar.  Repeat for each location.

2)  Wipe each location with a Lysol disinfectant wipe 3 times, wait for the area to dry.  Then rub the Q-tip across the area 3 times and rub the Q-tip across the petri dish with nutrient agar.

3) Observe the petri dishes each day for one week.  Record the number of bacteria colonies in each dish on a table.  Take photos daily of each petri dish.

By Brian, Alex, and Cameron

A and C were the easiest to guess. I think this is because you are most likely to have them around your house. B is less common to have in your house but for D is easily to have gotten mixed up with other fragrances. I thought A would be the easiest to guess because it is very strong, but most people guessed orange.

The more common the item is the easier it is to identify.

Name: Christian Andrew Jahnel
Title: Chemicals that pollute
Text:
-Metals and solvents from industrial work can pollute rivers and lakes. These are poisonous to any forms of aquatic life and may slow their development, make them infertile or even result in death.
-Pesticides are used in farming to control weeds, insects, and fungi. Run-offs of these pesticides can cause water pollution and poison aquatic life. Subsequently, birds, humans and other animals may be poisoned if they eat infected fish.
-Petroleum is another form of chemical pollutant that usually contaminates water through oil spills when a ship ruptures. Oil spills usually have only a localized affect on wildlife that can spread for miles. The oil can cause death of many fish and stick to the feathers of seabirds causing them to lose the ability to fly.
Look at this website:

http://www.water-pollution.org.uk/chemical.html
